content.text: Once upon a time, on the edge of a great forest, there lived a poor woodcutter with his wife and his two children. The boy was called Hansel, and the girl was called Gretel.
They had very little to eat, and once, when a great famine swept over the land, the woodcutter could no longer provide even their daily bread.
One evening, as the children lay in bed, they heard their stepmother say to their father, "We cannot feed the children anymore.
Tomorrow, we will take them deep into the forest and leave them there. They will never find their way home, and we shall be rid of them."
Hansel, who had overheard this cruel plan, crept out of bed and filled his pockets with small white pebbles that lay outside the house. Then he went back to bed and pretended to sleep.
The next morning, the stepmother woke the children early and gave them each a small piece of bread. "Come," she said, "we are going into the forest to cut wood."
Hansel crumbled his bread in his pocket and dropped the pebbles along the path as they walked. When they reached a deep part of the forest, the stepmother said, "Stay here and rest while we go to
cut wood. We will come back for you." But they did not come back. The children waited until nightfall, and then Hansel said, "Do not be afraid, Gretel.
The moon will shine soon, and then we shall find our way home." When the moon rose, the pebbles gleamed like silver coins, and the children followed them back to their father’s house.
Their stepmother was furious when she saw them, but their father was overjoyed. Not long after, the famine grew worse, and the stepmother again persuaded the woodcutter to abandon the children.
This time, she locked the door so Hansel could not go out to gather pebbles. Hansel had to leave a trail of breadcrumbs instead, but the birds of the forest ate them all.
The next morning, the stepmother took the children even deeper into the forest. She left them there, and when night fell, they could not find their way home.
They wandered for three days, growing hungrier and more tired, until at last they came upon a strange sight—a house made entirely of bread, with a roof of cake and windows of sugar. "Let us eat!"

cried Hansel, breaking off a piece of the roof. Gretel nibbled at the window. Just then, an old woman came out of the house. She seemed kind at first, inviting them inside and giving them a fine meal.
But the old woman was really a wicked witch who had built the house to lure children. The next morning, the witch locked Hansel in a cage and made Gretel do all the housework.
Every day, the witch would say, "Hansel, stick out your finger so I can feel if you are fat enough to eat." But Hansel, who was clever, stuck out a bone instead.
The witch, who had poor eyesight, thought he was still too thin. Weeks passed, and the witch grew impatient. "Gretel," she said one day, "heat the oven. We shall bake Hansel today!"
Gretel pretended not to understand, so the witch showed her how to test the oven. As the witch leaned over, Gretel gave her a mighty push and slammed the oven door shut.
The wicked witch was burned to ashes. Gretel ran to Hansel and freed him from the cage. They searched the house and found chests full of gold and jewels.
They filled their pockets with treasures and set off to find their way home. After many days of wandering, they came to a great river.
A white duck swam by, and Gretel asked, "Little duck, will you carry us across?" The duck nodded, and one by one, it carried them to the other side.
At last, they saw their father’s house in the distance. Their stepmother had died, and their father had grieved every day since they had been lost.
When he saw them, he wept with joy and embraced them tightly. Hansel and Gretel showed him the treasures they had brought, and from that day on, they lived in happiness and never knew
hunger again.
